article_text:
Republicans and conservative commentators are being roundly condemned for circulating misleadingly edited clips that purport to show Joe Biden being humiliatingly ignored in favour of Barack Obama at a White House event yesterday.

Mr Obama was making his first public speech at the executive mansion since he left office. He participated in a celebration of the Affordable Care Act, aka Obamacare, as Mr Biden announced changes to the healthcare programme that could see as many as 200,000 uninsured Americans become eligible for new coverage.

The visit has many Democrats hoping that Mr Biden can benefit from his former bossâ€™s still-high approval rating among the Democratic base. Mr Biden has lately struggled to raise his poor standing in the polls and there are serious worries that apathy and disappointment among Democratic voters could give an opening to Republicans in this yearâ€™s midterm elections. Mr Obama says that to win in the midterms, Democrats have a story to tell, they â€œjust got to tell it.â€

Key Points

Obama tells Democrats how to win midterms during White House return

Biden calls for â€˜brutalâ€™ Putin to face war crimes trial

Biden has privately said Trump should be prosecuted: Report

Secret Service â€˜command postâ€™ to protect Hunter Biden costs $360k a year

ICYMI: Biden extends student loan freeze a sixth time

15:44 , Andrew Naughtie

As Joe Biden remains under pressure from his party to cancel as much federal student loan debt as possible, his administration has once again pushed back the deadline for the resumption of payments frozen during the Covid-19 pandemic. This is the sixth time the deadlineâ€™s been moved, and will give debtors until at least 31 August.

Mr Biden has previously said he supports cancelling the debt altogether through congressional action, but his critics on the left say he has the power to do so unilaterally via executive action.

Josh Marcus has the story.

US to extend Covid student loan freeze until August 31

Story continues

ICYMI: Cruz bizarrely blames Biden for Ukraine war

15:20 , Andrew Naughtie

The Republican line on Ukraine, Russia and Vladimir Putin is still somewhat unclear, but the partyâ€™s more pugilistic members are sticking to one predictable version of events: blaming the unilateral Russian attack on an American ally on Joe Biden.

Ted Cruz took that line this week on Fox News, telling Sean Hannity that Mr Biden â€œcaused this warâ€ by waiving sanctions on the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline â€“ which in fact never became operational.

Backlash at Ted Cruz after he tells Fox News that Biden started war in Ukraine

Longtime Trump-watcher Aaron Rupar, whose monitoring of the former president and Fox News has made him a must-follow over the last several years, has called out two of Fox Newsâ€™s most-watched hosts for screening a misleading clip from yesterdayâ€™s White House event to smear Joe Biden as a failed, embarrassing president.

Dire economic warning from major bank

13:51 , Andrew Naughtie

Deutsche Bank has issued a stark forecast for the near future of the US economy, predicting that the country will fall into recession next year. Stocks will fall 20 per cent by next summer, says the bank, and unemployment â€“ currently at a remarkable low â€“ will rise by more than a percentage point in the next two years.

Coming from a bank, these specific predictions are unlikely to cut through the news cycle to everyday Americans, but the electorateâ€™s attitude to the economy is hardly optimistic as things stand.

Teenage shooter Kyle Rittenhouse, who killed two people at a Black Lives Matter protest in Kenosha in 2020, has long complained that Joe Biden bracketed him with â€œwhite supremacistsâ€ in a campaign ad â€“ and is now hitting out at the president over the intensifying probe into his sonâ€™s alleged financial misconduct.

Let me get this straight, Joe Biden can turn a blind eye to the misconduct of his own son, but defames me for defending myself?!

The White House yesterday announced a â€œwhole-of-government effort to prevent, detect, and treat Long Covidâ€, with plans including research into the conditionâ€™s causes and impacts not only on individuals but across populations. Long Covid has affected many people previously able to work to the point where they effectively have a new disability, meaning they may be entitled to new rights of which theyâ€™re unaware.

Barack Obama was in ebullient spirits during his White House visit yesterday, including when asked about the Democratsâ€™ prospects in what could be a punishing midterm election year. In a characteristically avuncular Obama-esque reply, he told a journalist the following:

NEW: Responding to my question what he says to Democrats worried about the midterms, President Obama tells me: â€œWe got a story to tell, just got to tell it.â€ pic.twitter.com/eBFsi0o9rA â€” Peter Alexander (@PeterAlexander) April 5, 2022

Joe Biden has nominated a new head of the US Coast Guard: Admiral Linda Fagan, who if confirmed would become the first woman to head a branch of the US military.

Maria Cantwell, head of the committee that will hold her confirmation hearings, remarked that â€œAdmiral Faganâ€™s nomination will inspire generations of American women to strive to serve at the highest level in the Armed Forcesâ€.

Biden nominating first woman to lead a branch of the US military

Will Obama and Bidenâ€™s bromance do anything for the Democrats?

10:01 , Andrew Naughtie

The Independentâ€™s Holly Baxter takes a look at yesterdayâ€™s White House appearance by Barack Obama, writing that it at least provided some welcome emotional warmth at a deeply negative moment...

there is something genuinely touching about the friendship. When Obama surprised Biden with the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2017 and Biden became overwhelmed with emotion, it wouldâ€™ve taken a heart of stone not to be moved. Biden is the kind of man for whom America and its pageantry really does mean everything, a man who spent most of his life shuttling between Scranton, Delaware and DC. Obama gave him the best gift he could ever have received â€” until the country did one better and voted him president, of course. Yet Obama was mostly silent during Bidenâ€™s presidential run, endorsing him late and staying out of the conversation when he was busy debating fellow Democrats. The world was hungry for more from the old bromance, back when politics felt a little simpler. And this week, Uncle Joe and Barack did some fan service.

At the same time, though, she ponders whether the visit can really offer much to Democrats as the president struggles around the 40 per cent approval mark and his agenda faces ongoing obstruction in Congress.

Read her take below.

Obama is doing bromance fan service with Biden. But is it enough?

Analysis: the worst of the KBJ hearings

09:25 , Andrew Naughtie

As the confirmation of Ketanji Brown Jackson draws near, Andrew Feinberg has this look back on the depths that were plumbed at her hearings by the Judiciary Committeeâ€™s Republican contingent and their colleagues on the Senate floor.

â€œRepublican senators,â€ he writes, â€œspent the majority of their speaking time in both settings airing grievances regarding Democratsâ€™ treatment of prior nominees going back to the Senateâ€™s rejection of Judge Robert Bork more than three decades ago. They also subjected Jackson, a Harvard Law School graduate who has thrice been confirmed by the upper chamber (twice to court seats and once to a seat on the US Sentencing Commission), to some of the most bizarre inquiries ever directed at a nominee for the highest court in the land.â€

Read his full rundown below.

The most ridiculous questions senators asked Ketanji Brown Jackson

(None of the stories he tells are in the same category as Marjorie Taylor Greeneâ€™s declaration that the three GOP senators voting to confirm Ms Brown Jackson are â€œpro-paedophileâ€.)

In widely-shared video clips â€“ that many have said are out-of-context â€” the president can be seen raising his hands in exasperation as a group of people showered Mr Obama with attention.

Illinois Republican Representative Adam Kinzinger criticised members of his party on Tuesday for what he sees as their unwillingness to speak out against the crisis in Ukraine.

â€œWe are being governed by a bunch of children,â€ Mr Kinzinger said. â€œBy a bunch of people that are not serious about running the United States of America and truly donâ€™t understand the threat thatâ€™s out there from Vladimir Putin, from China and from some of these actors in the world that want to destroy our place here.â€

â€œThe world order is being challenged for the first time since World War II and theyâ€™re sitting around thinking today about how we can win our next election, what the newest outrage is, whatâ€™s the next thing we can do to get people angry and upset and get their money from them for our reelection,â€ he added.

â€œWe got a story to tell, just got to tell it,â€ he said in response to NBC Newsâ€™ Peter Alexander.

Obama tells Democrats how to win midterms in first White House return in five years

Homeland security secretary takes a meeting with Republican caucus over border restrictions

05:01 , Maroosha Muzaffar

Homeland security secretary Alejandro Mayorkas on Tuesday had a meeting with House GOP members of the â€œborder security caucusâ€ but the Republicans were â€œnot satisfied with the answers.â€

The Border Security Caucus â€” after last weekâ€™s announcement that the White House would lift all Trump-era Covid restrictions at the border â€” was fully charged during the meeting.

â€œIt was a rough crowd, and you got to give him a lot of credit for picking the roughest crowd, going in, and listening to them,â€ Darrell Issa, a California Republican who attended the meeting said.

â€œNothing was really resolved, other than he made a promise to give a number of follow-up pieces of information,â€ he said.

Representative Brian Babin of Texas, the co-chairman of the caucus said of the meeting: â€œWe appreciated his courage to come in, knowing that we were opposed to him 100 per cent. But we were not satisfied with the answers he gave us.â€

Biden to extend Covid student loan freeze until 31 August

04:45 , Oliver O'Connell

The US is once again extending its pandemic-era pause on federal student loan repayments, pushing back the restart date until at least 31 August, the Associated Press reports.

This marks the sixth time the deadline to resume payments has been extended, as Joe Biden faces pressure from Congress and inflation worries.

Prior to the extension, the moratorium was set to expire on 1 May, and more than 43 million Americans with a collective $1.6 trillion in government loans were going to be on the hook again for their debt.

Josh Marcus reports.

US to extend Covid student loan freeze until August 31

US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin hits back at Matt Gaetz

04:00 , Oliver O'Connell

US Secretary of Defence Lloyd Austin appeared so incensed by outlandish lines of questioning from Republican congressman Matt Gaetz that he ended up in a shouting match with the Florida representative by the end of Mr Gaetzâ€™s five minute round.

Mr Austin was on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to testify at a House Armed Services Committee hearing regarding the Defence Departmentâ€™s fiscal year 2023 budget request, but Mr Gaetz had apparently decided to use his time to berate the former US Central Command boss about what he described as US defence failures caused by the Pentagonâ€™s embrace of â€œwokenessâ€.

Specifically, Mr Gaetz enquired about a lecture delivered at the US National Defence University by French economist and author Thomas Picketty entitled â€œResponding to China: The Case For Global Justice and Democratic Socialismâ€.

Oklahoma state House votes to make abortion illegal

02:30 , Oliver O'Connell

The Oklahoma state House voted overwhelmingly to pass a bill making it a felony to perform an abortion in the state punishable by up to 10 years in jail, in what is possibly the most restrictive anti-abortion bills passed since the US Supreme Court first signaled its willingness to curtail reproductive rights last year.

The legislation, which would punish any Oklahoman who performs an abortion with a lengthy jail sentence and a fine of up to $100,000, passed the state Senate last year before sailing through the state House by a margin of 70-14 on Tuesday.

Governor Kevin Stitt is expected to sign the bill.

Oklahoma state House approves bill to make abortion illegal with punishment
